Focuses on the one-to-one, face-to-face communication in both the personal and professional realms.
Such topics as verbal and non-verbal interactions, listening, and the better management of interpersonal communication will be studied.

In this course, we will work to understand more fully how we communicate (and are communicated to) in the world we live in and to develop the tools to research, apply, and practice key interpersonal communication concepts in our everyday lives.

Students will be encouraged to identify, negotiate, and challenge existing communicative norms as they explore a range of interpersonal and intrapersonal issues that include culture, identity, and power.

In this course students in Architectural, Civil, Environmental, and Geological Engineering will enhance oral and written communication competencies in contexts relevant to the engineering profession.
In this course, you will work to enhance your written and oral technical communication competencies in contexts relevant to the engineering profession as well as to your future career.

More generally, in this course, you should anticipate learning what professional norms of technical communication and dominant forms of sharing knowledge prevail within and across the fields of engineering.
Yet this course also attempts to impart awareness and appreciation for how these communicative forms are matters of social context and sites of negotiation and contestation.

By extension, this progression also encourages you to find a place and voice in the conversations within your fields of study and to reflect upon the meaning and shape of available forums for technical communication.
I perceive our classroom as a co-constructed space, in which readings and discussions may frequently challenge your attitudes, your unconsciously held beliefs, or your positions on current issues.
To ensure a safe and open space in which all can converse and learn productively, it is vital that we conduct our relationships with respect and an ethic of care.
Describe and apply conventions, genres, norms, and values of communication in an engineering discipline;
Compose persuasive, audience-specific technical arguments;
Analyze and summarice technical content in clear and concise ways;
Deliver effective oral presentations; and
Appraise and reflect on their own compositions, and those of their peers, to strategically revise and edit documents and presentations
Objectives for Students of Communication Studies
You (students) will understand the complexity of communication as a human process of shared meaning-making in the context of power, history, and culture.

You will increase your capacity to recognize and enhance yours and others’ agency – the ability to make a difference in the world for yourself and others – and understand the implications of your communication behaviors for yourself and others.
Recognize diverse linguistic practices and modes of communication as resources for writers and speakers.

You will understand communication as a practice, and improve your critical and creative communication competencies by developing your ability to use writing, speaking, and other media of communication to create effective and engaging artifacts.

Your will reflect on your role in fostering the public good (the multifaceted well-being of individuals and groups), begin to imagine a better future, and make decisions in your communication that can transform the communities to which you belong.

course_name: COMMST192 - Communication in the Engineering Profession (COMPE, ELE, MGTE) (0.50)
major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: D. Shakespeare
In this course students in Computer, Electrical, and Management Engineering will enhance oral and written communication competencies in contexts relevant to the engineering profession.

By participating in classes and completing course assignments, you will practice genres of communication crafted for audiences that might include employers, clients, peer groups, technical staff, public audiences, and regulatory and policy-focused stakeholders.
By focusing on genre, design, and audience, you will come to better understand concepts including meaning-making, perception, and responsibility.
More generally, in this course, students can and should learn professional norms of technical communication and dominant forms of sharing knowledge within the fields of engineering.
Yet this course also attempts to teach students how these communicative forms are matters of social context and sites of negotiation and contestation.
We also hope students will find their place and voice in the conversations in their fields of study and reflect on the meaning and shape of available forums for technical communication.
describe and apply conventions, genres, and norms, and values of communication in an engineering discipline
compose persuasive, audience-specific technical arguments
analyze and summarize technical content in a clear and concise way
You (students) will understand the complexity of communication as a human process of shared meaning-making in the context of power, history, and culture.

You will increase your capacity to recognize and enhance yours and others’ agency – the ability to make a difference in the world for yourself and others – and understand the implications of your communication behaviours for yourself and others.
You will recognize diverse linguistic practices and modes of communication as resources for writers and speakers.

You will understand communication as a practice, and improve your critical and creative communication competencies by developing your ability to use writing, speaking, and other media of communication to create effective and engaging artifacts.

You will reflect on your role in fostering the public good (the multifaceted well-being of individuals and groups), begin to imagine a better future, and make decisions in your communication that can transform the communities to which you belong.

major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: Introduction to Linguistics Winter 2025
ENGL 306A
Introduction to linguistics and the principles of linguistic analysis through an examination of English phonology, forms, syntax, and discourse.
View requirements for ENGL 306A
Introduction and Overview
English 306A, Introduction to Linguistics, covers the core areas of linguistics: phonology, morphology, syntax, and semantics.
Linguistics is a very diverse field, and the course brushes on many other topics, but it is organized around these central areas, exploring the units and the structures that make up human languages.
Phonology studies the units and structures of sound in language; morphology, the units and structures of words; syntax, of sentences; semantics, of meaning.
We study what it means for a native speaker to know and use a language: they need to know the sounds, the words, the way words group together, and how those word groups fit into a web of meaning.
That's a lot just to get someone to pass you the salt or agree that the Leafs sucked last night, but you deploy those systems effortlessly every day.
You should also know the general ways in which those elements combine—the types rules and processes that arrange the basic building blocks.
Some of the tools you should acquire are the ability to analyze words and sentences at a general level, and to transcribe sounds broadly.
You won't quite be ready to go into the jungles of Borneo and completely describe the grammar of an unknown language, but you should know in a basic way how someone who can perform that feat does it.
You should also come to a fuller awareness of the rules in your own head: how it is that your brain stores and retrieves and decodes language.

Understand a thorough representation of the most common conventions of English written and oral communication.
Analyze a diversity of English communications to ascertain the structure and infer the intended effects of communicator’s grammatical choices.
Evaluate English communications for their use of common grammatical conventions.
Compare and describe the grammatical structure of texts written in different styles and varieties of English.
Apply common grammatical conventions to combine and compose English written communications.
Explain the difference between prescriptive and descriptive approaches to grammatical analysis of sample communications.
Critique grammatical feedback for its application of common conventions and its reflection of understanding vs. perceived correctness.

Write persuasive and well-informed arguments about the grammatical structure of a communication, its use of common conventions, and to what extent the communicator’s choices influence the intelligibility of the communication.

DWE 3522
Room EV1-356/356A
This course provides an introduction to strategies and tools that enhance the effectiveness and impact of communications for environmental professionals.
View requirements for ENVS 131
This course introduces strategies and tools that enhance the effectiveness and impact of communications for environmental professionals.

We consider communications across a range of fields in which environmental professionals find themselves working: academia; journalism; business; government; advocacy and activism; and the creative arts.

The course focuses on practical topics such as: clear and persuasive writing techniques; critical reading and writing; effective presentation methods in small or large group settings; digital presentation techniques; media relations; oral communication skills; and corporate communications strategies.
Use environmental communications theories to critically analyze socio-ecological processes and problems:

-Deconstruct narratives about nature and the environment and how they relate to political ideologies; Illustrate how risk communication theory helps explain societal responses to environmental crises;
2. Identify and evaluate strategies and tactics for marketing, environmental advocacy and the communication of environmental science/risk;
3. Develop and deliver informed opinions about controversial environmental issues by critically examining multiple perspectives:
-deliver a persuasive and well-supported argument through writing and oral presentation;
-feel more confident and capable of engaging in respectful and fruitful oral discussions and debates about contentious environmental topics;
Identify and appreciate different forms of communication in your academic and professional careers, civic life and inter-personal relationships;
i. Distinguish between argumentative, analytical and expository writing styles;
Distinguish between, and describe the limits of, academic freedom, free speech, freedom of expression;
Paraphrase the ideas of others into your own words;
Feel confident engaging in “small talk;”
Compare and contrast marketing, advertising and public relations;

How can we use photography to communicate and engage people about sustainability?
In this course, you’ll learn how to use photographs to communicate and engage people about sustainability.
Everything you learn will come together in a major project, where you'll use photographs and text to communicate ideas relating to a sustainability topic of your choice.
In-person sessions focus on skills building through practising concepts and techniques discussed in readings and pre-recorded material.
Through three skills-building assignments, described below, you’ll develop your technical skills and practice idea-driven photography using groups of pictures.

To complete this assignment, you’ll choose and research a topic, conduct independent background research, develop a portfolio of images designed to communicate and engage people about sustainability or unsustainability, and prepare supporting text.
Peer mentoring and support are critical during the course, not only during critique sessions (where we help each other strengthen our images and ideas) but also during workshops and labs.
The course runs on a blended in-person and online format.
Students meet each week for one in-person class session in the Faculty of Environment Design Studio (EV3 2402).

Gain a better understanding of the strengths and limitations of photography as a tool for communicating ideas about sustainability

Practice printing and curation skills in support of photography projects

View requirements for FINE 130
FINE 130: Introduction to Digital Imaging is a studio-based Fine Arts course taught asynchronously online.
Students are encouraged to produce creative image-based projects throughout the term.

This course gives students introductory instruction and experience in creating original artwork using digital imaging tools and software and helps students develop a visual language to discuss their own work through artist statements.
While students will attain a degree of familiarity and comfort with the tools and techniques used to create digital artwork, there is a strong emphasis on content, conceptualization, and originality.

Through online lectures, tutorials and discussions, students will gain an understanding of the language used to discuss digital technologies and a critical context for the politics, power, and history of digital technologies and image making, and the impact of technologies on contemporary art practices.

Demonstrate successful use of core digital imaging tools and techniques like image compositing, masking, retouching, text, painting and drawing tools, and various other tools through hands on experience with industry standard digital imaging software.
Assess and critique digital imaging strategies and techniques in peer assessment writing assignments.
Develop a critical eye in relation to the elements and principles of design and contemporary image making techniques and practices.
Develop a critical eye in relation to the elements and principles of design and contemporary image making techniques and practices.
Discuss the historical precedents and artistic movements that continue to influence the explosion and ubiquity of images in our digitally saturated culture.

major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: Climate change is a complex phenomenon at the intersection of social and ecological systems.

An understanding of the fundamental science of climate change is only part of the challenge; evidence-based decision-making depends on communicating science effectively, and engaging diverse perspectives.

This course introduces the fundamentals of climate change communication, moving from linear to dynamic, context-dependent models of communication that draw directly from our knowledge of climate change.
Design a communication intervention based on theories reviewed in the course.
Tailor climate messaging to a variety of audiences.
Describe various heuristics and biases that are relevant to climate communication.
Engage in persuasive techniques designed to overcome motivated reasoning.
Design data visualizations relevant to climate change using best practice in the field.
Identify misinformation and suggest methods for overcoming misinformation.
Describe how journalistic norms can negatively impact public perceptions of climate change.
Communicate on technical topics without the use of field-specific jargon.
Design a questionnaire with attention given to question order, proper wording, and avoiding common survey pitfalls.
What subconscious biases guide environmental decision making?
How do these biases influence our risk perceptions and our support of different technologies?
How can we apply understanding of environmental psychology to better improve climate communication for the purpose of achieving our climate goals?
Broad overview of critical concepts including: motivated reasoning, audience segmentation, messaging frames, and deep canvassing.
Assessing the scope and importance of misinformation and evaluating strategies to combat misinformation.
How do we communicate uncertainty?
How can we improve at making probabilistic statements?
Do scientists who advocate for climate action or make political statements lose credibility?
********* Feb 17 Reading Week *******
Feb 24 Data visualization
What pitfalls should we avoid when visualizing climate data?
March 3 Climate in the media
How do journalistic norms influence climate change communication?
What incentives motivate journalistic choices?

topics: INTEG 210
Email: rob.gorbet@uwaterloo.ca
Collaboration and teamwork are essential for solving complex, real-world problems and are therefore in high demand by employers.
View requirements for INTEG 210
Collaboration is essential for solving complex, real-world problems.
What problems do teams most commonly face and how can those problems be minimized?
How can productive conflict increase creativity and productivity, and how can destructive conflict be reduced?

This offering of the course is designed explicitly for students enrolled in a parallel interdisciplinary capstone project (iCapstone), to help prepare them to be more effective collaborators in that context.
In the first half of the course, you will learn about factors which influence group dynamics and effectiveness, such as conflict styles, psychological safety, and the importance of trust.
As you do so, you’ll have a chance to reflect on your own strengths and weaknesses in team settings and use feedback from your peers to improve your collaborative skills.
By providing timely content on team and collaboration science and process, it equips students to be successful in their interdisciplinary capstone teams.
Apply appropriate theory and best practices to cultivate positive group dynamics
Cultivate a collaborative mindset: appreciate the benefits of diversity, embrace productive conflict, develop epistemic humility, cultivate empathy, and be open-minded
Better understand who you are as a collaborator and how you can help yourself and others be more effective collaborators

Psychological safety
Conflict styles & conflict management
Conflict style results & brief reflection (individual)

Focuses on the one-to-one, face-to-face communication in both the personal and professional realms.
Such topics as verbal and non-verbal interactions, listening, and the better management of interpersonal communication will be studied.

In this course, we will work to understand more fully how we communicate (and are communicated to) in the world we live in and to develop the tools to research, apply, and practice key interpersonal communication concepts in our everyday lives.

Students will be encouraged to identify, negotiate, and challenge existing communicative norms as they explore a range of interpersonal and intrapersonal issues that include culture, identity, and power.
Understand the complexity of communication as a human process of shared meaning- making in the context of power, history, and culture

Increase your capacity to recognize and enhance yours and others’ agency – the ability to make a difference in the world for yourself and others – and understand the implications of your communication behaviours for yourself and others

major_name: Bachelor of Computer Science Degree Requirements

Designed specifically for students for whom English is not the first language, this course introduces group discussion strategies and presentation skills.
A focus on pronunciation and vocabulary assists learners to better engage in conversations and listen to and deliver English presentations.

This is achieved with the focus on gambits, voice quality, and speech clarity, which assist learners in developing strategies to better engage in discussions, and listen to and deliver English presentations in both remote and face-to-face contexts.

Use communication gambits and signpost language effectively during discussions as well as individual and team presentations
Use body language and space on stage to enhance the expression of ideas
Listen for main ideas and details of some selected TED talks to form opinions on current socio-cultural, educational, environmental, and technological issues
Critically evaluate various sources of information and then incorporate these sources in oral communication to create strong, academic support for their ideas

major_name: Bachelor of Computer Science Degree Requirements
topics: Clear Communication in English Writing Winter 2025

k33willi@uwaterloo.ca

Designed specifically for students for whom English is not the first language, this course offers sentence-level instruction in grammar and idiom to teach students to produce, evaluate, and edit writing under time constraints.
It emphasizes readability and error reduction in sentences and paragraphs.
Identify sentence organization patterns and use them accurately and appropriately.
Consider the importance of purpose and audience for specific writing tasks.
